overview: Beginning January 1, 2026, this measure requires that pharmacy technicians be registered with and obtain a certificate of registration issued by the Board of Pharmacy. [16] It imposes a duty on pharmacists-in-charge to report violations by registered pharmacy technicians to the Board of Pharmacy. [16] The measure also specifies that supervising registered pharmacists are responsible for the actions of registered pharmacy technicians and pharmacy interns. [16]
agency_impact: In addition to any other powers and duties authorized by law, the board shall issue certificates of registration for registered pharmacy technicians. [15] The board may fine, suspend, or revoke any registration or permit for any cause prescribed by this chapter, or for any violation of the rules adopted under this chapter. [15] All proceedings for denial, suspension, fine, or revocation of a registration or permit on any grounds specified in subsection (a) shall be conducted pursuant to chapter 91. [15]
economic_impact: Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter or the rules adopted pursuant to this chapter shall be fined no less than $100 (HB72_CD1_.HTM.txt) and no more than $1,000 (HB72_CD1_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [15]
policy_impact: This measure amends Chapter 461, Hawaii Revised Statutes, by adding a new section requiring a certificate of registration for pharmacy technicians. [15] It amends section 461-4.5, Hawaii Revised Statutes, to include issuing certificates of registration for registered pharmacy technicians as a duty of the board. [15] Section 26H-6, Hawaii Revised Statutes, shall not apply to this Act. [15]
revenue_sources: Your Committee on Conference has amended this measure by deleting the $20 (HB72_CD1_CCR182_.htm.txt) registration fee for pharmacy technicians. [16] A new revenue source is established through fines for violations, which shall be no less than $100 (HB72_CD1_.HTM.txt) and no more than $1,000 (HB72_CD1_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [15]
six_year_fiscal_implications: Beginning January 1, 2026, no person shall act as a pharmacy technician without first obtaining a valid certificate of registration issued by the board. [15] Each certificate of registration shall be valid through December 31 of each odd-numbered year, upon which the registration shall lapse and a new registration shall be required. [15] The Board of Pharmacy's duty to issue certificates of registration will be an ongoing administrative cost. [15] The Board may also fine, suspend, or revoke any registration, which will incur costs related to proceedings conducted pursuant to chapter 91. [15] [15] The state will forgo biennial revenue due to the deletion of the $20 (HB72_CD1_CCR182_.htm.txt) registration fee. [16] A recurring, but indeterminate, source of revenue will be fines of no less than $100 (HB72_CD1_.HTM.txt) and no more than $1,000 (HB72_CD1_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [15]
operating_revenue_impact: The Conference Committee amended the measure by deleting the $20 (HB72_CD1_CCR182_.htm.txt) registration fee for pharmacy technicians, which eliminates a potential source of operating revenue. [16] The bill creates a new, variable stream of operating revenue from fines, as any person who violates the chapter shall be fined no less than $100 (HB72_CD1_.HTM.txt) and no more than $1,000 (HB72_CD1_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [15]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: The requirement for pharmacy technicians to obtain and renew a certificate of registration is ongoing, as renewals are required biennially on or before December 31 of each odd-numbered year. [15] The administrative costs for the Board of Pharmacy to issue certificates, renew registrations, and conduct disciplinary actions will continue indefinitely. [15] [15] Revenue from fines for violations will also be a recurring, though unpredictable, fiscal component. [15]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: A key amendment to the measure is the deletion of the $20 (HB72_CD1_CCR182_.htm.txt) registration fee for pharmacy technicians. [16] The bill now establishes specific fines for violations, which shall be no less than $100 (HB72_CD1_.HTM.txt) and no more than $1,000 (HB72_CD1_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [15] The registration requirement for pharmacy technicians is now set to begin on January 1, 2026. [16] The measure codifies that supervising registered pharmacists are responsible for the actions of registered pharmacy technicians and pharmacy interns. [16] The specific duties of the Board of Pharmacy are expanded to include issuing certificates of registration and taking disciplinary action against registrants. [15] [15]
